Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Comprehensive Energy Storage Solutions in Electrified Transportation

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program. Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

This planning grant will lay the groundwork for a new NSF Engineering Research Center, CESSET: Comprehensive Energy Storage Solutions in Electrified Transportation with the proposed mission to match the accelerating needs of our society for mobility and accessibility with sustainable and renewable energy. Given that fossil-fuel-based transportation is a major source of pollution worldwide, immense opportunities exist to deflect the planet's climate trajectory by electrifying transportation with renewable, decarbonized power sources assisted by dynamically controlled distributed energy resources. It is expected that the innovation CESSET is aiming to bring will reverse the stark projections of human-created climate change and air-pollution. Beyond health benefits, such a transformation will have positive economic impact by dramatically reducing oil imports and by reconfiguring domestic manufacturing.

This new transportation future requires research into advanced energy storage. Although the automotive industry has started the trend towards vehicle electrification and there is significant funding for energy storage, progress has been slow and compartmentalized. In preparation for a new Center-scale research effort, a rigorous scoping study is needed to reveal synergies, identify the most impactful research directions, develop strategies that will foster integration between disciplines, and secure the correct combination of expertise and partner institutions. In this planning grant, CESSET's strategy in achieving its vision will be formed with special emphasis on developing multidisciplinary course and training programs, and influencing national and international policy and market trends. In the context of the proposed planning grant, impact beyond university research will be pursued through a series of meetings and workshops with stakeholders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcome of this planning grant was the development of an Engineering Research Center (ERC) proposal on Comprehensive Energy Storage Solutions for Electrified Transportation (CESSET). The Center if awarded will bring together intellectually diverse researchers to tame the largest source of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the United States—the transportation sector—with a novel engineered battery system ecosystem through an unparalleled, holistic approach that synergizes innovative battery systems research with policy, economics, education and workforce development in a close, collaborative partnership with industry and community partners. To truly succeed, we aim to make electrified transportation accessible to all people, including low and middle-income households who have been historically priced out of the existing electric vehicle market.

 Intellectual Merit: CESSET will integrate interdependent, yet historically isolated engineering efforts by linking models, sensing, data analytics, power electronics, controls, materials chemistry, economics, and life cycle analysis all within one dedicated research center. In doing so, CESSET will establish informative feedback loops that will enable breakthroughs that result in a seamless, scalable, and highly compatible set of technologies for a transformative engineered system. Our engineered system will embody the 3-R principles our children learn at school, Reduce, Reuse and Recycle: (1) Reduce inefficient battery utilization with novel battery design and predictive management and reduce range anxiety with fast charging and better accessibility to charging infrastructure. (2) Reuse aged automotive batteries by repurposing them to the grid to support fast charging stations and maximize penetration of renewables. (3) Recycle degraded batteries based on judicious decisions from life cycle analysis of the environmental impact and levelized cost estimates. CESSET will integrate four multidisciplinary Thrust Areas (TAs) to achieve these outcomes. TA1- IMPROVE will characterize, model, and synthesize novel cell designs needed to boost rechargeability and sustainability. TA2- EXTEND will develop innovative sensing, accurate parameter identification, robust detection, and health prognostics to maximize the utilization of fresh and aged batteries and push them to their limits. TA3- INTEGRATE will enable flexible charging through novel designs and management of on-site storage and local grid loads and repurposed batteries for high penetration of renewables. Finally, TA4-SUSTAIN will analyze the circular economy of sourcing, use, repurposing, and recycling feeding back to local supply chains and manufacturing. All four thrust areas will be supported with three crosscutting efforts in testbeds, co-simulation, and data. This integrated plan received overwhelming support from over 70 businesses, startups, national laboratories, municipalities, and educational institutions.
Broader Impacts: With its home base at the University of Michigan, in a region known for its rich history of manufacturing and automotive innovation, and partners at UC San Diego, San Diego State, UC Davis, and Carnegie Mellon, whose research is at the forefront of microgrids and environmental policy, CESSET will ensure an accelerated transition to electrified mobility. This transition will not only be at a rate and scale that will avert irreversible environmental damage, public health and economic losses, but also in a way that will prepare the workforce for a just transition to a new era of mobility. Along with embedding CESSET students in a dynamic environment that will nurture their leadership and scholarship, we are committed to understanding what populations may be at risk of losing their jobs due to changing economic forces. Together with our educational partners, we will develop a plan to train the workforce in the skills necessary for the e-mobility transition, as well as new curriculum and degree programs. We will partner with local governments to usher in the policies necessary to maximize the economic, environmental and societal benefits of a green electrified transportation system.
